ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Canvas reading files and discussion posts
live lecture and readings
Online zoom discussions, though we had individual meeting with our professor to discuss our essay drafts.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Writing, analysis, discussion skills
How to become a stronger writer and critical thinker!

My analytical skills improved greatly throughout this course, along with my writing abilities. I have become much stronger in my explanatory skills and have learned how to be much more precise and clear.
I learned a lot more about how to effectively discuss literature, as well as how to write more succinctly and clearly. She really taught me how to more effectively write research papers.
How to write depending on form
i learned the art of essay writing and how to properly discuss some classic novels.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great syllabus, fascinating discussions, and a wonderful professor! I wish we could connect a little bit more as a class (this was made difficult over zoom, but Perusall really helped).
This course was one of my favorites, I could not really name a weakness. It was extremely interesting and engaging, and gave an interesting perspective on love and relationships.

She is an incredible professor. You can tell that she truly cares about her students and wants them to succeed. You can also tell that she absolutely loves the material that she's teaching, an infectious energy that made all of her lectures incredibly fun. This was my favorite course of the semester.

some weaknesses were that it was kind of repetitive with the reading and then discussion but that may have been mostly credited to covid. strengths were that the instructor was very good with trying to keep engagement even when the vibe was low.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The teacher always made an effort to get the conversation going and create fun discussions even with zoom. Obviously, zoom fatigue is very real, but even so, the class was engaging and enlightening. The last one we even went 15 minutes over because no one wanted to leave!
Success: discussions, Perusall, and screensharing writing tips.
This course was as good as it couldve been in terms of covid accommodations. Having the live virtual lectures was much better than if it had been asynchronous.

She tried a new format of having us all annotate on a virtual notebook, which could be seen by everyone, which I thought was a lot of fun. Our readings translated well to virtual format and our discussions were also a blast.
Virtual seminar worked

the discussion was kind of repetitive and that was sort of due to COVID since we couldnt really do anything else other than read and discuss over zoom. however, the discussions were very interesting and they didnt feel forced. people chimed in when they had something to contribute.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES!!! Maggie is a wonderful and incredibly supportive professor! Don't be afraid to ask her for help during draft conferences! The readings were super fun  and compelling (Madame Bovary, Persuasion, Gaitskill's short stories). "Narrating Desire" sounds cheesy but there's so much more to it! Why is desire cheesy? What is desire? Fantasies? Imagination? Cliches? All things you'll explore throughout the course.
Yes, I would recommend this course to every incoming freshman, it was an amazing course and the small size of the class was great for hearing everyones perspective on things.
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Not only is the material so fun, Maggie is an incredible professor and I truly enjoyed every minute of the course throughout the semester.
Absolutely
this course and the instructor was very reasonable and fair. the workload was not heavy at all so therefore i would recommend this course to others.
